resource.chars:
are blended together that they Seeme to constitute an even 
whitenesse. But when the rayes pass through the Prisme 
to the eye, the orbits of the Seuerall colours in every ring are 
refracted, Some more then others according to their degree of refrangi 
bility: by wch means the colours on one side of the Ring become 
more unfolded & dilated & on the other side more complicated &
contracted. And where by a due refraction they are soe much 
contracted that the seuerall rings become narrower then to 
interfere with one another, they must appeare distinct, & also 
white, if the constituent colours be so much contracted as to be 
wholy coincident. But on the other side, where every Ring is 
made broader by the further unfolding of its colours, it must 
interfere more with other Rings then before, & soe become lesse 
distinct 
To explaine this a little further, suppose the concentrick 
circles AB & CD represent the red and violet of any Order, wch 
together with the intermediate colours constitute any one of these 
Rings. Now these being viewed through a Prisme the violet circle 
BC will by a greater refraction be further translated from its place 
then the Red AD, & so approach nearer to it on that side towards wch 
the refractions are made. For instance; if the Red be translated 
to ad, the violet may be translated to bc, soe as to approach nearer 
to it at c then before; & if the Red be further <s>to<\s> translated to ad,
the violet may be so much further translated to bc as to convene 
with it at c, and if the Red be yet further translated to [alpha delta],
the violet may be still so much further translated to [beta gamma], as to 
passe beyond it at [gamma], & convene with it at e & f. And this being 
understood not onely of the red & violet, but of all the other 
intermediate colours, & also of every revoluc[i]on of those colours,
you will easily p[er]ceive, how these of the same revoluc[i]on or 
Order by their nearnesse at cd & [delta gamma], & their coincidence at cd, e,
& f, ought to constitute pretty distinct Arcs of circles, especially 
at cd or at e & f, and that they will appear Seuerall at cd, at cd 
exhibit whitenesse by their coincidence, & againe appear Seu[er]all 
at [delta gamma], but yet in a contrary Order to that wch they had before, &
still retaine beyond e & f. But on the other side at ab, ab, or
[alpha beta]

are blended together that they Seeme to constitute an even 
whitenesse. But when the rayes pass through the Prisme 
to the eye, the orbits of the Seuerall colours in every ring are 
refracted, Some more then others according to their degree of refrangi 
bility: by wch means the colours on one side of the Ring become

contracted. And where by a due refraction they are soe much

made broader by the further unfolding of its colours, it must 
interfere more with other Rings then before, & soe become lesse 
distinct

to it at c then before; & if the Red be further <s>to<\s> translated to ad,
the violet may be so much further translated to bc as to convene 
with it at c, and if the Red be yet further translated to αδ,
the violet may be still so much further translated to βγ, as to 
passe beyond it at γ, & convene with it at e & f. And this being 
understood not onely of the red & violet, but of all the other 
intermediate colours, & also of every revoluc[i]on of those colours,
you will easily p[er]ceive, how these of the same revoluc[i]on or 
Order by their nearnesse at cd & δγ, & their coincidence at cd, e,
& f, ought to constitute pretty distinct Arcs of circles, especially 
at cd or at e & f, and that they will appear Seuerall at cd, at cd 
exhibit whitenesse by their coincidence, & againe appear Seu[er]all 
at δγ, but yet in a contrary Order to that wch they had before, &
still retaine beyond e & f. But on the other side at ab, ab, or
